{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3312429,"name":"Brendan R.","username":"Braykoff","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/braykoff/{size}/204536_2.png","created_at":"2024-02-18T20:00:12.420Z","cooked":"

We have a neo550 with a 2 stage ultraplanetary gearbox on it, a 4:1 and a 5:1. Whenever we assemble these, the amount of torque required to turn them (with no load) is larger than the neo550 can handle.

Both the gearboxes work when we turn them by hand individually. The neo550 spins well without any gearboxes. When the gearboxes and neo are put together, they spin well by hand. It is when we put the screws through them and tighten them that the problem begins. Upon tightening the screws to any degree, the gearbox completely locks up and cannot be turned by hand. Running the motor just makes it heat up. The only way to get it to spin is essentially to not put the screws in at all, or leave them not all the way in (the head a couple mm from being flush with the gearbox).

The screws are the correct size, they do not bottom out at all.

Deconstructing the gearbox reveals that friction between the gears and the top plates of each planetary stage is leaving marks/indentations.

The only way we can think of to solve this is putting washers between every stage so they don’t hit each other. Is there a proper solution to this?

You might be overtightening them or have the motor mounting plate backwards

Make sure you are using the correct screws in the base stage of your Ultraplanetary. In the hardware pack there are 2 specific rounded head M3 screws specifically for bolting the base plate onto a motor. If any other screws are used it will push into the first stage of the gearbox and cause it to bind.

The torque spec we got from rev for the assembly bolts was finger tight or there abouts. Just barely tighten them and use plenty of locktite. They work great if you don’t over tighten.

In our first season using them we over tightened and got marks all over the inner shields, but once we started just snugging the screws and using plastic safe locktite they been great to us.
